summary: This document is a chain of email correspondence from March to June 2019, primarily between federal prosecutors and administrative staff, requesting and approving travel for the investigation into Jeffrey Epstein (case 2018R01618). The travel is for conducting victim interviews and meetings in Los Angeles and West Palm Beach/Fort Lauderdale, Florida.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the federal investigation (United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618) for enticement of minors for sexual activity.

connections.description: Co-workers and fellow federal prosecutors traveling together for the Epstein investigation to conduct victim interviews.
S is a federal prosecutor investigating Epstein for enticement of minors.
M is a federal prosecutor investigating Epstein for enticement of minors.

events.title: Initial Travel Request for Florida Interviews
events.description: Prosecutors S and M request travel approval for a two-day trip to West Palm Beach and/or Fort Lauderdale, Florida, for meetings and interviews related to the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Travel Approval for Florida Trip
events.description: Travel is approved for prosecutors to go to West Palm Beach, Florida, for approximately three days to conduct meetings and interviews for the Epstein case.

events.title: Follow-up Travel Request for Florida
events.description: Prosecutors request another approximately three-day trip to West Palm Beach, Florida, for victim interviews, noting the need to pin down timing with victims.

events.title: Travel Request for Los Angeles Interview
events.description: Prosecutors request travel to Los Angeles for a victim interview, planning to fly down on Wednesday and return by Friday, and to reserve a hotel conference room for the interview.

keyFacts: The document references the federal criminal case 'United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618', investigating the enticement of minors for sexual activity.
Federal prosecutors were actively traveling to conduct victim interviews in multiple cities (Los Angeles, West Palm Beach, Fort Lauderdale) in the spring of 2019.
The correspondence shows a pattern of requesting permission to reserve hotel conference rooms specifically for conducting victim interviews.
The investigation was ongoing and involved coordination for scheduling interviews with victims, whose timing was sometimes uncertain.
The email chain demonstrates administrative procedures within the U.S. Attorney's Office for approving investigative travel.
